labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: How to react to a Status-Realm-Request that contains authentication credentials
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
Section 5.1 ([Status-Realm-Request Packet](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#name-status-realm-request-packet)) declares:
> Status-Realm-Request packets MUST NOT contain authentication credentials (such as User-Password, CHAP-Password, EAP-Message) or User or NAS accounting attributes (such as Acct-Session-Id, Acct-Status-Type, Acct-Input-Octets).

It does not declare how a RADIUS Server should respond when it receives a packet that contains authentication credentials.  Should the server silently reject?  Should it reject with an error code, possibly a new one for [Section 7](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-7-4)?  Should it strip the credential and forward it along as an otherwise normal Status-Realm request?

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body:
probably add a new error code saying `invalid contents`

it's likely better to return an error, instead of stripping the attributes and forwarding them.

comments.author: meadmaker
comments.body: I also prefer to return an error code.  I'll write an update to do so.

issues.title: What is the difference between response codes 4 and 258?
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body: Both say the target realm is "missing or invalid."  What is the difference  between them?  How should clients react differently when they receive one or the other?

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body: I think those should be two separate cases.

comments.author: meadmaker
comments.body: Ironically, I had a typo when I entered this issue; I meant to ask about code 3, instead of code 4.  This has been brought up in #8, so I'll have the conversation over there.

issues.title: In Server-Information, would a Server-IP-Address sub-attribute be useful?
issues.author: meadmaker

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body: There may be privacy issues here? It's worth while to define it, as I can see people using it for internal proxies.  But the text should say it's not required.

comments.author: meadmaker
comments.body:
I'll go ahead and define the sub-attribute, then.

The text says that the Server-Information attribute MUST have at least one sub-attribute, and MAY have more than one, but does not specify that any particular one is required.  I think that should convey that the IP address sub-attribute is not required.

I'll also add some text in the Security Considerations about the information exposure that this represents.

issues.title: Should we have an explicit requirement for `@` in Status-Realm requests' User-Name field?
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
[Section 9.1](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-9.1-3) states:
> The RADIUS Client MUST include a User-Name attribute in the request. The "user" portion of the username SHOULD be omitted. The "realm" portion of the username is the target realm for the Status-Realm request.

Is it worth being explicit about whether the `@` part of the User-Name is required?  On the one hand, it would be easy to assume that all you need is `example.com`; on the other hand, if you look up the definition of the User-Name attribute, you eventually discover that the `@` is required if you want to describe a realm.  That said... you have to bother to wade through multiple documents before you discover the definition of a Network Access Identifier that requires the `@`.

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body:
I'd say that the User-Name portion MUST be omitted when the NAI format is used.  As a reminder, NAI is `@realm` where `realm` is a DNS hostname.  See RFVC 7542 Section 2.5:

`Realms MUST be of the form that can be registered as a Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) within the DNS.`

Some sites MAY use User-Name formats other than NAI, but that's outside of the scope of this specification.

issues.title: Ports and RadSec
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
[Section 9.1](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-9.1-6) declares:
> RADIUS Clients MAY send Status-Realm-Request packets to the RADIUS destination ports from the same source port(s) used to send other Request packets. Other RADIUS Clients MAY choose to send Status-Realm-Request packets from a unique source port that is not used to send other Request packets.

This seems to be discussing how the protocol should work over plaintext UDP.  Does anything need to change for RadSec?

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body: I think the current text is OK, and doesn't need to change for radsec

issues.title: Message authenticators and RadSec
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
[Section 9.2](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-9.2-3) declares:
> If a server supports Status-Realm, is configured to respond to Status-Realm-Requets, and receives a Status-Realm-Request packet from a permitted RADIUS Client, it MUST first validate the Message-Authenticator attribute as defined in [[RFC3579](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#RFC3579)], Section 3.2. Packets failing this validation MUST be silently discarded.

I don't remember off the top of my head how the Message-Authenticator is treated under RadSec.  Is that still used, or should this be updated to reflect that this is for plaintext UDP only?

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body: radsec doesn't change the use of Message-Authenticator.  So this is fine.

issues.title: Does "available" mean "Is it alive/dead", or does it mean "Is it configured at all"?
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
[Section 9.3](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-9.3-4) states:
> In some cases, a RADIUS proxy may not have an available next-hop RADIUS server for the Target Realm. In that case, the RADIUS proxy server MUST send a Status-Realm-Response packet indicating that there is no proxy route to the Target Realm (Status-Server-Response-Code = 1).

"Available" could be talking about either the question of whether the RADIUS proxy is configured to know about the Target Realm at all, or it could be talking about whether the RADIUS proxy thinks that the next hop RADIUS server is reachable (alive/dead).  Which of these does this paragraph describe?  Should the behavior be different between these two cases?

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body:
I think this overlaps with issue #8.  If we separate the failure codes into blocks, we can better distinguish "unreachable realm" from "unknown realm"

we can also distinguish the failure cases:

* I have no connections to the next hop
* I have connections, but the next hop is not responding
* I know about the realm, but I'm not configured to route it anywhere (not sure when this would happen)

And the other failure cases are things like "I don't know what the heck `@xyz.123` is"

comments.author: meadmaker
comments.body:
> * I know about the realm, but I'm not configured to route it anywhere (not sure when this would happen)

This happens commonly in eduroam deployments, where a national operator is authoritative for a top-level domain, and so it knows all of the possible valid entries.  Think of it as saying, "Yes, I know that `oxfrod.ac.uk` does not exist because I am authoritative for `.uk`."

issues.title: Incorrect code number used?
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
[Section 9.3](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-9.3-5) says:

> If the proxy is configured not to forward Status-Realm-Request packet to the Target Realm and does not have other methods to detect the status of the Target Realm, it SHOULD return a Status-Realm-Response packet indicating that the request is administrative prohibited (Status-Server-Response-Code = 257)

[Section 7](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-7-4) says:

>    256      Administratively prohibited, target realm status unknown
>    257      Internal error, target realm status unknown

Is this an accidental mismatch, or am I missing how that description maps to that attribute?

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body:
probably a typo.

I'm not sure what the difference is between "administratively prohibited" and "internal error".

`3` and `258 also seem to overlap.

Perhaps we want to separate the errors into blocks, as with the `Error-Cause` attribute:

200-299 are various success indicators
300-399 are server failures (I know the realm, but it is not currently routable)
500-599 are signallng failures (I don't know the realm, or the realm format is invalid)

issues.title: Fill in example exchanges
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body: Sections 10.1 and 12.1 want to give message exchange examples, but are not filled in.

issues.title: text on Identifiers
issues.author: alandekok
issues.body:
It's worth adding a note in `Status-Realm-Request Packet` that the RADIUS Identifier field MUST be tracked separately for this packet.

i.e. there's no overlap between Access-Request identifiers and this one.

issues.title: authentication versus accounting
issues.author: alandekok
issues.body:
The text says

`Status-Realm-Requests may be sent to the RADIUS authentication port or the RADIUS accounting port of the first-hop RADIUS server....`

Maybe say "packets received on an authentication port should be forwarded to the authentication port of the next hop"

but what if the server receives auth+acct on the same port (e.g. radsec), and then splits that out to two different ports on the next hop?

or what about testing CoA paths?  The CoA proxy document says "proxy on Operator-Realm".

Perhaps we want a new attribute which defines what kind of packet it's supposed to track?  i.e.

attribute Follow-Path is integer, and contains an 8-bit RADIUS packet type (Access-Request, Accounting-Request, CoA-Request).  Proxies choose a forwarding path based on this attribute.

this could also give a way to probe remote servers.  i.e. send Status-Realm with "follow-path = accounting" to an authentication port.  the server can either process it as normal, OR reply with an error "I don't accept accounting on this port".

That gives a _positive_ acknowledgement as to what packets are accepted on what port.

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body:
* have a `Route-As` attribute with packet types (Access-Request, Accounting-Request, CoA/Disconnect-Request)
* auth + acct are routed on User-Name.
* CoA / disconnect are routed on Operator-Name, to match RFC 8559

issues.title: Proxy-State
issues.author: alandekok
issues.body: The `RADIUS Loop Prevention Overview` section has comments on `Max-Hop-Count`.  It's likely worth adding a note that proxied packets MUST have `Proxy-State` added, as per RFC 2865 Section 5.33.

issues.title: Do we want to probe the full set of paths?
issues.author: alandekok
issues.body:
The Status-Realm packet probes a particular path, but the original client doesn't control which path.  Each proxy chooses a path to probe, and only the results for the chosen path are returned to the client.

we could conceivably allow for probing of multiple paths through one of two methods:

1) an attribute "avoid path".  This would contain a list of Server-Identifiers taken from a Status-Realm-Response.  A proxy could then see if it's listed there, and if so, choose a _different_ next hop than what is listed.

2) an attribute "probe all paths".  In which case a proxy would see this, and then send packets out all possible paths.  On the reply, it would need to merge the results back into one reply to the client.

Option (1) seems simple.  Option (2) is more complex, because it allows for explosion of packets by sending 1.  And the only way to stop that explosion is to have some kind of globally unique packet identifier.  When there are multiple / overlapping paths, intermediate proxies would then have to track this identifier, and suppress sending the same thing again.

Option (1) may leak a little bit of information about path A when a packet is sent over path B, but that's a small issue.

issues.title: How to deal with detected loops
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
[Section 11.2](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-11.2-2) states:

> Before forwarding a RADIUS Request towards the Target Realm, a RADIUS Proxy that implements Proxy Loop Prevention MUST examine each of the Server-Information attributes included in the Request message to determine whether the message is caught in a Proxy Loop. If so, the Proxy should discard the message. 

Should the loop-detecting Proxy Server reject the authentication instead of dropping it silently?

comments.author: meadmaker
comments.body: If rejecting, the Proxy Server should indicate somehow which server detected the loop.

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body:
I think the server which detects the loop should return an error with "loop detected".

If the Server-Information attribute is still added, then the loop can be detected by looking for two Server-Information with duplicate contents.

issues.title: The table of attributes in section 15 should have headers for attribute type and attribute name
issues.author: meadmaker

issues.title: Table of attributes: Should we remove the entries that are never sent?
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
[Section 15](https://meadmaker.github.io/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm/draft-ietf-radext-status-realm.html#section-15-2) contains a table of attributes, including how many times each attribute will be included in a Status-Realm request packet and response packet.

Further, that section declares:
> Attributes other than the ones listed below SHOULD NOT be found in a Status-Realm-Request packet

Does that imply that we should remove all the table attributes that have a quantity of 0 and 0?  This includes:
- User-Password
- CHAP-Password
- EAP-Message
- Digest-*

issues.title: Does "traceroute" require Max-Hop-Count?
issues.author: meadmaker
issues.body:
Section 4.2 includes:

```
RADIUS Clients can also use the Max-Hop-Count attribute to implement "traceroute-like" functionality. By setting the Max-Hop-Count value to a series of increasing values, it is possible to discover the proxies which route packets to a target realm.
```

However, if a Status-Realm response includes a full set of Server-Information attributes, then the route could be discovered with only one request, rather than a set of requests with an increasing Max-Hop-Count.

pulls.title: Return error when Status-Realm request contains user credential
pulls.author: meadmaker
pulls.body:
The draft says that Status-Realm requests MUST NOT contain credentials, but doesn't say how to react if a request packet does.  Update to specify an error code to return in this case.

Fixes #1

pulls.title: Define Server IP Address sub-attributes in Server-Information
pulls.author: meadmaker
pulls.body:
Define sub-attributes for v4 and v6 addresses, and suggest that people configure the values of any NAT system as the values, when applicable.

Also, include in the Security Considerations that this has the potential to divulge information, and again suggest that people configure the RADIUS server to return the publicly known IP addresses when applicable.

Fixes #3

comments.author: alandekok
comments.body:
Maybe we want to list a table of attributes and say:

Server-Identifier OR Server-IP-Address OR Server-IPv6-Address.  Just like the similarly named NAS-*

pulls.title: Use the "@realm" form of the NAI
pulls.author: meadmaker
pulls.body:
Change to be explicit about having the User-Name attribute's value be a Network Access Identifier of the second form, "@realm".

Fixes #4

pulls.title: Rework the response codes
pulls.author: meadmaker
pulls.body: Taken from discussion in #8, rework the Status-Realm response codes.

pulls.title: Create markdown tables from ASCII art tables
pulls.author: meadmaker

pulls.title: Fix some typos and reformat the document
pulls.author: Janfred
pulls.body:
* Fix some typos
* Instead of stating the referenced RFCs in the header, use different format
  * `{{!RFCXXXX}` for normative references on first occurence
  * `{{?RFCXXXX}` for informative references on first occurence
  * `{{RFCXXXX}` for reoccuring references
  * `{{RFCXXXX, Section Y}}` for referencing with link to section
* Change some informative references to normative references
  * RFC2869 and 3579 (Message-Authenticator)
  * RFC5580 (Definition of Operator-Name)
  * RFC7542 (Format of NAI)
* Remove section for "Interaction with RADIUS Client MIB Modules
  * Merge into the previous section (MIB Considerations)
